[Assess] Bracero Farmworker Case Study

üìç Coachella Valley, CA

Published

September 19, 2025

Class Overview

  • Centering activity
  • Setting the stage
  • Paired coding
  • Group Debrief

Centering Activity

Setting the Stage

  • This week‚Äôs focus is on data tidying and transformation
  • Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped
  • Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program

Let‚Äôs get Started

  • Find your pair
  • Open Posit

First Steps

  • Import Data
  • Load packages
library(readxl) # for loading data
library(tidyverse) # for tidying
# | eval: true
# | echo: false
bracero <- read_excel("~/Google Drive/My Drive/Teaching/ES-202/data/week_03/bracero_pull.xlsx")

Part II: Today‚Äôs Goal

  • Understand data
  • Transform and tidy data for necessary questions
  • Explore and summarize patterns
  • Connect it to theoretical understandings of procedural justice

Our data

  • 90 rows (interviews)
  • 6 variables (all chr type)
    • title = Person interviewed
    • subject = topic of interview
    • description = summary of interview
    • date = date of interview
    • identifier = link to original interview file
    • language = language interview was conducted in
glimpse(bracero)
Rows: 90
Columns: 6
$ title       <chr> "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶
$ subject     <chr> "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶
$ description <chr> "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee:  Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶
$ date        <chr> "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶
$ identifier  <chr> "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶
$ language    <chr> "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶

Data Types

  • chr is character
  • dbl is double (number)
  • int is an integer
  • dttm is date-time
  • fct is factor

Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of?

$ language    <chr> "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶

Transforming Data (Columns)

  • Four functions can change the columns of your data without affecting your rows
    • mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones
    • select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe
    • rename(): changes the names of current columns
    • relocate(): changes the position of those columns

mutate() function

  • We use the mutate function to change the date column to a date format.
bracero |>
  mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) 
# A tibble: 90 √ó 7
   title               subject description date  identifier language date_format
   <chr>               <chr>   <chr>       <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <date>     
 1 Richard Hancock     Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng      2003-04-21 
 2 Pedro Cantor        Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27 
 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n  Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      2006-05-22 
 4 Vincente Delgado    Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      2005-09-01 
 5 Inez Rios           Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng      2003-01-31 
 6 Manuel Enriquez Sa‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      2003-02-06

10 Jos√© G. Corral      Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      2005-11-12 
# ‚Ñπ 80 more rows

mutate() function (cont.)

  • We can also use mutate for creating new columns, and we can pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements.
  • Perhaps we were interested in creating a new column that defines whether an interview is from a bracero worker or not.
    • Note that if we wanted to further classify the subject, we might create a factor column and use the fct_collapse function, rather than an ifelse statement.
bracero |> 
  mutate(subject_binary = ifelse(subject %in% c("bracero", "Bracero"), "Bracero", "Non-Bracero" )) 
# A tibble: 90 √ó 7
   title            subject description date  identifier language subject_binary
   <chr>            <chr>   <chr>       <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>         
 1 Richard Hancock  Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng      Non-Bracero   
 2 Pedro Cantor     Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      Bracero

10 Jos√© G. Corral   Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa      Non-Bracero

select() function

  • Perhaps we‚Äôd like to remove the original date column from our dataframe.
  • select() can be used to select or deselect columns.
# select column you don't want
bracero |>
 select(-date)

# select columns you do want
bracero |>
 select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, date_format)

# select columns in a row, except the column you don't want
bracero |>
  select(title:description, identifier:date_format)

rename() function

  • sometimes original column names aren‚Äôt very descriptive, or they‚Äôre too long.
  • the rename() function can help.
    • let‚Äôs rename ‚Äútitle‚Äù to something more descriptive.
bracero |>
  rename("interviewee" = "title")
# A tibble: 90 √ó 6
   interviewee              subject        description date  identifier language

relocate() function

  • Say we want the identifier column at the very end of the dataframe
  • relocate automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify .after or .before.
bracero |> 
 relocate(identifier, .after = language)
# A tibble: 90 √ó 6
   title                    subject        description date  language identifier
   <chr>                    <chr>          <chr>       <chr> <chr>    <chr>     
 1 Richard Hancock          Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng      https://b‚Ä¶
 2 Pedro Cantor             Bracero        "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa      https://b‚Ä¶
 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n       Bracero        "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ spa      https://b‚Ä¶
 4 Vincente Delgado         Bracero        "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa      https://b‚Ä¶
 5 Inez Rios                Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng      https://b‚Ä¶
 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ spa      https://b‚Ä¶
 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez  Bracero        "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa      https://b‚Ä¶

Put it together

  • We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the pipe |> function
bracero_clean <- bracero |>
  mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) |>
  select(-date) |>
  rename("interviewee" = "title") |>
  relocate(identifier, .after = date_format)

head(bracero_clean)
# A tibble: 6 √ó 6
  interviewee              subject   description language date_format identifier
  <chr>                    <chr>     <chr>       <chr>    <date>      <chr>     
1 Richard Hancock          Do√±a Ana‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng      2003-04-21  https://b‚Ä¶
2 Pedro Cantor             Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27  https://b‚Ä¶
3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n       Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2006-05-22  https://b‚Ä¶
4 Vincente Delgado         Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-09-01  https://b‚Ä¶
5 Inez Rios                Interact‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng      2003-01-31  https://b‚Ä¶
6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau o‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2003-02-06  https://b‚Ä¶

Exercise One

  • Starting with the bracero dataframe, code the following three actions using the |> into a new dataframe:

    • mutate the date column to be in a DD-MM-YYYY format called date_format
      • hint: you may need to use the ?as.Date() helper function
    • select the title , date_format, and descriptioncolumns
    • reorder the remaining columns by alphabetic order

Transforming Data (Rows)

  • Moving on to rows!
    • filter() is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won‚Äôt change the order of your rows)
    • arrange() changes the order of your rows (but won‚Äôt filter for anything)

filter() function

  • Use the filter() function to select rows that correspond to values of interest.
  • Say we‚Äôre interested in only interviews that are spoken in spanish:
  • use == to filter for a direct match
bracero_clean |>
  filter(language == "spa")
# A tibble: 75 √ó 6
   interviewee              subject  description language date_format identifier
   <chr>                    <chr>    <chr>       <chr>    <date>      <chr>     
 1 Pedro Cantor             Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27  https://b‚Ä¶
 2 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n       Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2006-05-22  https://b‚Ä¶
 3 Vincente Delgado         Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-09-01  https://b‚Ä¶
 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2003-02-06  https://b‚Ä¶
 5 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez  Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27  https://b‚Ä¶
 6 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres       Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-08-31  https://b‚Ä¶
 7 Jos√© G. Corral           Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-11-12  https://b‚Ä¶

10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez  Bracero  "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27  https://b‚Ä¶
# ‚Ñπ 65 more rows

filter() (cont.)

  • You can also combine multiple conditions:

    • > = greater than

    • >= = greater than or equal to

    • < = less than

    • <= less than or equal to

    • == equal to

    • != does not equal

    • Can use & to combine conditions

    • | for or

  • Perhaps we‚Äôre interested in interviews that took place after 2004 in English:
bracero_clean |>
  filter(date_format >= 2004-01-01 & language == "eng")
# A tibble: 15 √ó 6
   interviewee               subject description language date_format identifier
   <chr>                     <chr>   <chr>       <chr>    <date>      <chr>     
 1 Richard Hancock           Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng      2003-04-21  https://b‚Ä¶

filter() and str_detect()

  • We can also combine filter with str_detect()
bracero_clean |> 
  filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto"))
# A tibble: 3 √ó 6
  interviewee              subject description   language date_format identifier
  <chr>                    <chr>   <chr>         <chr>    <date>      <chr>     
1 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez  Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-27  https://b‚Ä¶
2 Alberto Magall√≥n Jim√©nez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa      2005-07-28  https://b‚Ä¶
3 Alberto Mendoza Torres   bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa      2003-09-26  https://b‚Ä¶

arrange()

  • arrange() sorts your rows based on the values in the columns.
  • If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to ‚Äúbreak ties‚Äù
  • including desc() wills sort your column values big to small.
bracero_clean |> 
  arrange(date_format, interviewee)
# A tibble: 90 √ó 6
   interviewee             subject   description language date_format identifier
   <chr>                   <chr>     <chr>       <chr>    <date>      <chr>     
 1 Heriberto Cort√©z Cort√©z Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-05-13  https://b‚Ä¶
 2 Homero L√≥pez Ortiz      Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-05-31  https://b‚Ä¶
 3 Patricio Corrales Rojas Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-07-02  https://b‚Ä¶
 4 Liborio Santiago P√©rez  Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-07-06  https://b‚Ä¶
 5 Gregorio Corrales Rojas Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-07-09  https://b‚Ä¶
 6 H√©ctor Sol√≠s Fuentes    Bracero   "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa      2002-07-10  https://b‚Ä¶

Exercise Two

  1. Filter the bracero_clean dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 with an interviewee whose name includes ‚ÄúGuadalupe‚Äù.

  2. Sort the bracero_clean data frame in descending order by date. What was the date, how many interviews took place, and who is listed first?

  3. Filter the bracero_clean dataframe for any interviewees that mention ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äù. How many interviewees mention California?

  • If you‚Äôre interested in reading descriptions, you can type ‚Äúbracero_clean$description[]‚Äù with the row number in brackets to print the description in your environment window.

Grouping Data

group_by() function

summarize()

Exercise Three

  1. How many Braceros were interviewed in this dataset (i.e., Bracero is the topic)? Use a group_by function to count.
  • Hint: R is case-sensitive.
  1. How many non-braceros were interviewed in this dataset?
  2. Based on the non-bracero topics, can you create a new factor column that groups the topics into 3-5 factors?
  • use mutate(), and fct_collapse() to classify the groups into a new column called topic_group
  1. Are there any interesting patterns in language spoken among your topic_groups? Use a group_by and summarize function to calculate.

Exercise Four

  1. Listen to an interview with Mr. Cris Luna, a Bracero from Ozuluama, Veracruz, Mexico.

interview with Mr. Raymundo Villa, an interpreter from Ysleta, Texas who worked with

Explore the Bracero archives, and listen to or read the biographical descriptions of interviews in the ‚ÄúOral History‚Äù section. 2. Reflect on the aspects of procedural injustice as they relate to othe Bracero program: -
